column4: is there a way to install files using the web instead of apt-get install but end up with the same file?
what do you mean "using the web"?
firefox for example
well for the case where i don't want to apt-get update but I just want one program?
i've seen it for debian
if you want one program, you "apt-get install <program>" (or "aptitude install <program>", which i would say is better) -- i don't understand you either
online access for the tarballs that I could manually compile the same sources that apt-get would grab.
for a live session
if you actually want to *compile* the stuff, just "apt-get source <program>" and you'll have the sources in your current directory
burner but there is a source specific to ubuntu somewhere that apt-get grabs, all i'm asking is if I can use firefox to download the source instead of apt-get.
yes, you can. but what does this have to do with compiling from source? anyway, of course you can use firefox, just look at the repository's URL, and give it to Firefox
excactly what i'm after the web address of the repository
I cant find it anywhere
look in /etc/apt/sources.list - and then, for the exact subdirectory of a single package, "apt-cache show <package>" will show you
could you paste it for me
my /etc/apt/sources.list is hosed
!tell Grock about sources
again I have to ask how to access the ubuntu repository search it and download with firefox new applications
so when apt-get install doesn't work can i use firefox to get stuff from the repositories?
yes, and then you can install it using "dpkg -i <filename.deb>". i don't quite see why you *should* do this, but anyway
keep in mind, though, that many packages have dependencies, i.e. they need other packages to work -- so, often, downloading just *the* package you want is not enough!
